sen.j: 寿司（すし、鮨、鮓、寿斗、寿し、壽司）と呼ばれる食品は、酢飯と主に魚介類を組み合わせた日本料理である。
sen.e: Food called sushi (described as 寿司, 鮨, 鮓, 寿斗, 寿し or 壽司 in Japanese) is Japanese cuisine combining vinegared rice mainly with seafood.
sen.cmt: 「すし」を表す漢字の違いを表すため、漢字を併記しました。
sen.e: Food called sushi (described as 寿司, 鮨, 鮓, 寿斗, 寿し or 壽司 in Japanese) is Japanese cuisine combining vinegared rice mainly with seafood.
Food called sushi (described as 寿司, 鮨, 鮓, 寿斗, 寿し or 壽司 in Japanese) is Japanese cuisine combining vinegared rice mainly with seafood.

sen.j: 大別すると、生鮮魚介を用いた「早鮨」系統のもの、魚介類に米を加えて乳酸発酵させた「なれ鮨」系統のものに区分される。
sen.e: Sushi is roughly classified into a group of 'Haya-zushi' (fresh sushi) using fresh seafood, and a group of 'Nare-zushi' (fermented sushi) which is seafood kept in rice and fermented by the action of lactic-acid bacillus.

sen.j: そのなかでも代表的な江戸前寿司は、すでに“sushi”で通じるほど世界中に認知されている。
sen.e: Edomae-zushi (hand-rolled sushi), representative sushi among them, is already recognized all over the world to such an extent that the term "sushi" is used as it is.

sen.j: 本来はタンパク質（主に魚肉や獣肉など）の保存方法の一つである。
sen.e: Sushi was originally one of methods to preserve protein (mainly of fish meat, game meet and so on).

sen.j: 「すし」は上方では「鮓」江戸では「鮨」の字があてられる。
sen.e: As to Chinese characters of sushi, '鮓' was used in Kamigata (Kyoto and Osaka area), but '鮨' was used in Edo.

sen.j: 延喜式の中に年魚鮓、阿米魚鮓などの字が見える。
sen.e: The Engishiki (an ancient book for codes and procedures on national rites and prayers) had terms of 年魚鮓 (Ayu-zushi (sweetfish sushi)), 阿米魚鮓 (Amenouo-zushi) and so on.

sen.j: 現代に伝わる古い鮓の形は近江地方の鮒鮓や熊野の年魚鮓である。
sen.e: A style of old sushi is handed down to Funa-zushi (crucian carp fermented sushi) in the Omi region and to Ayu-zushi in Kumano in the modern period.

sen.j: 魚の保存が主であり飯は付けたりとなる。

sen.j: この自然に酸くなるのを待てずに、飯の量を多くして酢を加えて作ったものが「すし」であり慶長のころから文献に見える。
sen.e: Sushi' was the result of adding vinegar to increased amount of rice because of being able to wait for becoming sour naturally, and appeared in literatures from the Keicho era.

sen.j: 「すし」の語源は江戸時代中期に編まれた『日本釈名』や『東雅』の、その味が酸っぱいから「酸し（すし）」であるとした説が有力とされている。
sen.e: A widely-accepted theory was that the term 'sushi' originated from 'sushi' meaning sourness due to its sourness as described in "Nihon Shakumei" (The Japanese Etymological Dictionary) and "Toga" (an etymological dictionary) compiled in the middle of the Edo period.

sen.e: Nigiri-zushi (sushi shaped by hand) is representative at present, but major kinds of sushi used for bento (lunch box) are Oshi-zushi (lightly-pressed piece of sushi topped with cooked ingredients), Chirashi-zushi vinegared rice with thin strips of egg, pieces of raw fish, vegetables and crab meat arranged on top), Maki-zushi (sushi roll) and Inari-zushi (fried tofu stuffed with vinegared rice).

sen.j: なれずし（馴れ寿司、熟寿司）は魚に塩と飯を混ぜて長期間保存し乳酸菌の作用によって発酵させたもの。
sen.e: Nare-zushi (described as 馴れ寿司 or 熟寿司 in Japanese) refers to sushi made through processes of mixing fish with salt and rice, preserving it for a long time and fermenting it by the action of lactbacillus.
sen.cmt: 「なれずし」が日本語ではどのように表記されるかを示すため、併記しました。
sen.e: Nare-zushi (described as 馴れ寿司 or 熟寿司 in Japanese) refers to sushi made through processes of mixing fish with salt and rice, preserving it for a long time and fermenting it by the action of lactbacillus.

Nare-zushi (described as 馴れ寿司 or 熟寿司 in Japanese) refers to sushi made through processes of mixing fish with salt and rice, preserving it for a long time and fermenting it by the action of lactbacillus.

sen.j: もともとは魚だけを塩蔵して自然発酵させていたが、16世紀前後に発酵を促進させるために飯を加えるようになったという。
sen.e: Originally, only the fish was preserved with salt and was fermented in a natural way, but, it is said that rice came to be added in order to promote fermentation in around the 16th century.
Originally, only the fish was preserved with salt and was fermented in a natural way, but, it is said that rice was added in order to promote fermentation in around the sixteenth century.

sen.e: "Cultivated Plants and the Origin of Agriculture" (1966) written by Sasuke NAKAO described that this method was one of cultural complexes of swidden cultivation of 'hill folks in Laos and tribe doing swidden agriculture in Borneo Island.'

sen.e: "Sushi Book" (1970) written by Osamu SHINODA described that preserved food of fish meat of hill folks in Southeast Asia was the origin of sushi, and was developed as a means of preservation of fish which was seldom available due to highland.

sen.j: 石毛直道・ケネス・ラドル著『魚醤とナレズシの研究 モンスーン・アジアの食事文化』（1990年）では、東北タイ王国やミャンマーあたりの平野部をあげ、水田地帯で稲作と共に成立した魚介類の保存方法が後に伝わったとしている。
sen.e: "Dietary Culture in Monsoon Asia based on the Research on fish sauce (soy sauce-like fish sauce) and Nare-zushi" (1990) written by Naomichi ISHIGE and Kenneth RUDDLE took plains in the northwestern part of Kingdom of Thailand and in Myanmar for instance, and described that a method to preserve seafood which was established along with rice cropping in paddy lands was handed down to subsequent generations.

sen.j: 中国では「鮨」の文字は紀元前5 - 3世紀に成立した辞典『爾雅』に登場し、「魚謂之鮨」とある。
sen.e: In China, a character of '鮨' appeared in "Jiga" (Erya) established in the 5th to 3rd centuries BC, and Jiga had a description that 'fish was so-called sushi.'
sen.cmt: 「鮨」という文字の起源にかんする記述なので、そのまま表記しました。

sen.j: 2世紀末成立の『釈名』では「鮓」は「魚の（塩と飯で漬け込んだ）漬け物、熟してから食べる」とされている。
sen.e: "Shakumei" (Etymological Dictionary) established at the end of the 2nd century described that '鮓' referred to pickled fish (pickled with salt and rice), and was eaten after being fermented.'

sen.j: しかし、三世紀頃に編まれた『広雅』からは、それまで別の意味であった「鮨（魚の塩辛）」と同じものとされており、「鮓」があまりポピュラーな食べ物ではなかったことがうかがえる。
sen.e: However, after "Guangya" (Expanded Erya) edited in around the 3rd century, '鮓' (pickled fish) was defined as the same as '鮨' (salted fish) which had been defined as a different one, which showed that '鮓' was not so popular food.

sen.e: "Yoro ritsuryo code" (code promulgated in the Yoro period) (718), one of the Japan's oldest reference records, and "Shozeicho" (balance sheets of tax rice) (729 - 749) also had descriptions of sushi, and it is considered that sushi had existed long before the reference records.

sen.j: ナマナレが現代に多く残った理由として、発酵時間が短く、早く食べられることがあげられようが、日比野光敏著『すしの貌』では「米を捨ててしまうのがもったいない」という感覚もあったのではないかと指摘している。
sen.e: A reason why namanare remains today in many places may be that short-time fermented makes it eatable earlier, but, in "Face of Sushi" written by Tetutoshi HIBINO, he pointed that this might be because people felt that 'it would be a waste to discard rice.'

sen.j: 時代が下るとともに酒や酒粕、糀を使用したりと、寿司の発酵を早めるため様々な方法が用いられ即製化に向かう。
sen.e: With the passage of times, various kinds of methods came to be used to accelerate the fermentation of sushi like using sake, sake lees or koji.

sen.j: そして1600年代からは酢を用いた例が散見されるようになる。
sen.e: And from the 1600s, examples of using vinegar came to be seen here and there.

sen.j: 岡本保孝著『難波江』に、「松本善甫という医者が延宝年間（1673-1680年）に酢を用いたすしを発明し、それを松本ずしという」とある。
sen.e: "Nabae" (Essay of Yasutaka OKAMOTO) written by Yasutaka OKAMOTO described that 'a doctor whose name was Yoshiichi MATSUMOTO invented sushi using vinegar in the Empo era (1673 - 1680), and this sushi was called Matsumoto-zushi.'
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: "Nabae" (Essay of Yasutaka OKAMOTO) written by Yasutaka OKAMOTO described 'a doctor whose name was Yoshiichi MATSUMOTO, invented sushi using vinegar in the Empo era (1673 - 1680), and this sushi was called Matsumoto-zushi.'

sen.j: しかし、日比野光敏によれば「松本ずし」に関する資料は他になく、延宝以前の料理書にも酢を使った寿司があるゆえ「発明者であるとは考えられない」としている。
sen.e: However, Terutoshi HIBINO metioned that 'it was hard to regard him as an inventor' because there were no other materials on 'Matsumoto-zushi,' and a cooking book before the Empo era also described sushi by using vinegar.

sen.j: 誰が発明したかはともかく、寿司に酢が使われ、酢の醸造技術も進んできて、いよいよ発酵を待たずに酢で酸味を得て食する寿司、「早寿司」が誕生することになる。
sen.e: Regardless of who invented sushi, as a result of using vinegar in making sushi, and advancement in technology of brewing vinegar, sushi which was acidulated by vinegar without waiting for fermentation, so-called 'Haya-zushi,' came into being.

sen.j: 「妖術と いう身で握る 鮓の飯」『柳多留』（文政12年 1829年 作句は1827年）が、握り寿司の文献的初出である。
sen.e: Senryu (humorous or ironical haiku), 'Form rice of sushi by hand as quickly as a sorcerer forms a round shape with fingers,' in "Yanagidaru" (a collection of senryu) (1829; year when the haiku was made was 1827) was the first description of Nigiri-zushi appearing in literatures.

sen.j: 握り寿司を創案したのは「與兵衛鮓」華屋與兵衛とも、「松の鮨（通称、本来の屋号はいさご鮨）」堺屋松五郎ともいわれる。
sen.e: It is said that Nigiri-zushi was invented by Yohe HANAYA of 'Yohe's Sushi,' or by Matsugoro SAKAIYA of 'Matsu no Sushi' (commonly called name; original name of shop was Isago Sushi).

sen.j: 『守貞謾稿』によれば、それまで江戸の寿司といえば、関西風の押し寿司が大勢をしめた。
sen.e: According to "Morisada Manko," conventional sushi in Edo mainly referred to Kansai-style Oshi-zushi.

sen.j: しかし、握り寿司が誕生すると、たちまち江戸っ子にもてはやされて市中にあふれ、江戸のみならず文政の末には関西にも「江戸鮓」を売る店ができた。
sen.e: However, when it was invented, Nigiri-zushi instantly became popular among natives of Edo, and came to be sold everywhere in the city, and at the end of Bunsei era, shops selling 'Edo Sushi' also appeared in Kansai.

sen.j: 天保の末年（1844年）には稲荷寿司を売り歩く「振り売り」も現れたという。
sen.e: In the last year (1844) of Tenpo era, 'sushi vendor' who carried Inari-zushi about for sale also appeared.

sen.j: このころには巻き寿司もすでに定着しており、江戸も末期、維新の足音も聞こえてこようかという時代になって、ようやく現代でもポピュラーな寿司が、一気に出揃ったわけである。
sen.e: At around this time, Maki-zushi was also rooted, and at the end of Edo period when the atmosphere of Restoration came close, a linr-up of sushi which is also popular today came into being at a burst.

sen.j: 明治30年代（1897年-）頃から企業化した製氷のおかげで、寿司屋でも氷が手に入りやすくなり、明治の末あたりからは電気冷蔵庫を備える店も出てくる。
sen.e: From around 1897, due to industrialized ice making, even sushi restaurants could obtain ice easily, and some restaurants started an installation of electric refrigerator at around the end of Meiji period.

sen.j: 近海漁業の漁法や流通の進歩もあって、生鮮魚介を扱う環境が格段によくなった。
sen.e: The progress in the fishing method of coastal fishery and in the distribution also led to a dramatic improvement of the environment handling fresh fish and shellfish.

sen.j: 江戸前握り寿司では、これまで酢〆にしたり醤油漬けにしたり、あるいは火を通したりしていた素材も、生のまま扱うことがしだいに多くなっていく。
sen.e: Foodstuffs for Edomae-Nigiri-zushi which used to be vinegared, soaked in soy sauce or cooked came to be used in fresh gradually in many cases.

sen.j: 種類も増え、大きかった握りもしだいに小さくなり、現代の握り寿司と近い形へ変化しはじめた時代である。
sen.e: It was also the time when the number of kinds increased, nigiri (a rice ball) which used to be big was sized down, and a transformation to a form similar to present-day Nigiri-zushi started.

sen.j: 大正12年（1923年）の関東大震災により壊滅状態に陥った東京から寿司職人が離散し、江戸前寿しが日本全国に広まったとも言われる。
sen.e: It is said that as a result of dispersal of sushi chefs from Tokyo which was devastated by the Great Kanto Earthquake in 1923, Edomae-zushi spread all over Japan.

sen.j: 第二次世界大戦直後、厳しい食料統制のさなか、昭和22年（1947年）飲食営業緊急措置令が施行され、寿司店は表立って営業できなくなった。
sen.e: Soon after the World War II, under circumstances where the food control was strict, the Emergency Restaurant Business Measures Ordinance was enacted in 1947, and it became impossible to operate sushi restaurants openly.

sen.j: 東京では寿司店の組合の有志が交渉に立ちあがり、1合の米と握り寿司10個（巻き寿司なら4本）を交換する委託加工として、正式に営業を認めさせることができた。
sen.e: In Tokyo, volunteers of sushi shops association stood up for a negotiation, and succeeded in obtaining an official license of business as processing on commission to make a trade of one go (unit of volume, approx. 0.18 liters) of rice for ten pieces of Nigiri-zushi (or four rolls of Maki-zushi).

sen.j: 関西をはじめ全国でこれにならったため、全国で寿司店といえば江戸前ずし一色となってしまった。
sen.e: Since sushi shops not only in Kansai but also in various places in Japan followed this, only Edomae-zushi came to be sold at sushi shops across the country.

sen.j: ちなみに1合で10個の握り寿司ならかなり大きな握りで、いわゆる「大握り」と呼ばれる江戸-明治初期を思わせる大きさである。
sen.e: For reference, if ten pieces of Nigiri-zushi had been made from one go of rice, the size of nigiri would have been rather big, and been as big as nigiri recalling the size of nigiri, so-called 'large piece,' in the period from the Edo period to the beginning of Meiji period.

sen.j: 当時を知る職人は、「あらかじめダミーの米を入れる袋を用意して店頭に置き、取り締まりを逃れて営業したこともある」と述べている。
sen.e: A sushi chef knowing that time said, 'we have operated a shop by preparing a bag to put dummy rice in and putting the bag at the shop so as to get away from the control.'

sen.j: 戦後の高度成長期になると、衛生上の理由から既に屋台店は廃止され、廉価な店もあるにはあるものの、寿司屋は高級な料理屋の部類に落ち着いた。
sen.e: In the high-growth period after the war, street stalls were already abolished on hygienic grounds, and although there were shops serving sushi at a moderate price, an idea that sushi restaurants was classified as high-class restaurant took root.

sen.j: サラリーマンを題材としたマンガでは、夜遅くまで外で飲み歩く亭主が、妻の機嫌を取るために寿司の折り詰めを買って帰るという姿が描かれる事もしばしばあった。
sen.e: Comics settling on the subject matter of office worker often showed a situation that a husband going bar-hopping until late at night bought and brought a box lunch of sushi in order to pay his court to his wife.

sen.j: 1980年頃にはすっかり日本各地で普及するに至り、寿司は家族で訪れるような庶民性も取り戻していった。
sen.e: In around 1980, due to such sushi bars and shops completely became popular in various places in Japan and was visited by families, sushi regained the common touch.

sen.j: 既に明治43年（1910年）華屋與兵衛の子孫、小泉清三郎著『家庭鮓のつけかた』には、ハム（またはコールドミート）を使ってコショウをふった巻き寿司があり、江戸前寿司（早寿司）は様々な材料を受け入れやすい素地があった。
sen.e: "How to Make Home-Made Sushi" written in 1910 by Seizaburo KOIZUMI who was a descendent of Yohe HANAYA already introduced peppered Maki-zushi using ham (or cold meat) as a filling, and Edomae-zushi (Haya-zushi) had an aptitude for accepting various kinds of foodstuffs.

sen.e: In the 1970s, sushi had a burst of popularity mainly on the West Coast of the United States, and 'California roll' developed under such circumstance had a great success and was brought back also in Japan.

sen.e: New ingredients for sushi and sushi' in the "Textbook of Sushi Techniques" in 1975 introduced as many as 100 kinds of new ingredients for sushi such as caviar, porcino, lobster, natto (fermented soybeans), junsai (water shield) and so on.

sen.e: Present-day sushi shops serve each and every kind of foodstuff as sushi, while sushi shops which stick to classical foodstuffs and technique also enjoy high popularity, and are regarded as a high-class restaurant serving expensive sushi.

sen.j: 長い鎖国が解かれ、明治になると移民として南米へ、北米へと渡る者も多く、各地で日本人コミュニティが生まれた。
sen.e: When the long national isolation ended and the Meiji period started, many Japanese people emigrated to South America and North America as immigrants, and Japanese communities were established in various places.

sen.e: In other countries, the work conducted by hand is considered as unsanitary, and there is a regulation demanding sushi chefs to wear thin rubber gloves or plastic gloves, but, Japan has no such custom because a method of preparing seafood eaten in fresh by hand is a very general method conducted even at home, and it is considered that rubber gloves or plastic gloves may dull a delicate sense of touch by chef's fingers.

sen.j: ただし日本国内でもスーパーなどで持ち帰りの寿司を作る場合や、回転寿司店で手袋を着用していることがある。
sen.e: However, sushi chefs making takeout sushi at supermarkets or making sushi at "conveyor belt" sushi bars sometimes wear gloves even in Japan.

sen.j: 昨今では、世界的な日本食ブームのおかげもあり、日本人以外のいわゆる「通」を自称する人々の間でも、「素手で握る寿司が一番」という風潮がある。
sen.e: Nowadays, thanks to worldwide of Japanese food, there is also a tendency to consider that 'sushi made by hand is the best' among non-Japanese people calling themselves so-called 'connoisseur.'

sen.j: これは単に伝統にこだわっているだけではなく、特に西洋人の間では「日本の寿司職人は、素手で握っても食中毒を起こさない衛生的で清潔な職人」という西洋人独特のイメージを大事にしたいという理由もあるという。
sen.e: This does not only stick to a tradition, but there is a reason that western people want to protect their own image that 'Japanese sushi chefs are as hygienic and clean as not causing food poisoning even making sushi by hand.'

sen.j: 会計は一つ一つの寿司に値段が掲示されていない場合が多い。
sen.e: Many sushi restaurants do not present a price of each sushi.
Many sushi restaurants do not present a price for each piece of sushi.

sen.j: これは寿司ネタが時価の影響を受けるからと言われている。
sen.e: It is said that this is because ingredients for sushi are affected by market prices.

sen.j: もちろん、値段の内訳は注文の際に店員に尋ねればきちんと答えてもらえる。
